captions.text:
- [Voiceover] Yeah, like
the first syllable of tiger.
- Uh-oh. We got one of those weird symbols
that I never knew what to do with.

- In a way that you
wouldn't expect, raisin.
- Rosheeeeen. So what does that symbol do?
- This one I should know because
there's an actress that has this name,
and she was in a Wes Anderson movie.

- These combination of
letters is just so strange.
- Sersha? These are really pretty names,
but I, they're spelled so weird.

- Guys, you tell me what
you do with an m and an h,

- Maybe it's just simple,
maybe it's just Cowmee.

- Some of these letters
are not being used.
It's just me figuring out which ones.

- Why is a e in there
if it has no purpose?

If there's no e in
Owen, oh, yeah there is.

- I don't know what the
little thing is above the e.
- So I think it would be Mairead, but

What is that, it's like a,
it's like a male parade.
- I don't even know what a's are anymore.
- Like Liam, but it's an n?
I am not getting that from this.

- This is a term of endearment
for your grandmother.
- I don't know how else to pronounce it

- There's literally no
other way to say this.

And if they say it a
different way, it's wrong.
- I feel like they can make a big comeback
Which, the Irish better watch out.

title: Americans Try To Pronounce Traditional Irish Names

comments.author: Siobhan Freeman

comments.text:
Okay, so like a fair few of the names in the video, aren't pronounced the 
way they're said in the video in my area, though I can't account for other 
parts of Ireland. It is annoying though that people keep referring to Irish 
as a dialect and acting as though it's not viable as a language. 
Generations of Irish people sought to preserve our language while being 
persecuted for using it. (I have nothing against the UK, it's just a fact.) 
It irritates me that SL many Irish people disregard the sacrifices those 
people made. Yes, English is used more commonly, but Irish is a part of our 
culture. It is a beautiful, ancient language, and we should be proud of it. 
Sin ár dteanga duchais!﻿
